div.head:
Embleme 27. Of the Secrets of Nature.
Hee that endeavours to enter into the Philosophers Rosary without
a key, is like him that would walke without feet.

lg.l: Roses in wisedom's garden doe abound,
But allwayes under locks and bolts is found:
One onely key it hath, of means esteeme,
Yet without that you swim against the streame.
He, that can scarce upon a levell stand,
In vaine attempts Parnassus to ascend.

div.head: Discourse 27.
div.ab:
Concerning Erichthonius they write, that hee sprung from the seed of Vulcan-
cast upon the earth striving with Pallas the Goddesse of wisedome, with ser
pentine and without humane feet. Very like him are those, who, depending upon
the means of Vulcan alone, without the wisedome of Pallas, doe begett monstrous
children, namely, without feet and abortive, which can neither sustaine-
themselves, nor profit others: It is a miserable thing for a man to goe on all
foure, that is, hands and feet together, but much more miserable to be all
together destitute of feet, and to use armes instead thereof: for they seem to
have degenerated to the nature of wormes, who goe after the manner of crea
ping wormes: But the two leggs are the organicke parts in man, without which
hee cannot truely walke, as neither see without eyes, or touch things tangible
without hands: soe likewise Medicine and every operative art is supposd to
have two leggs, whereon to stand, namely experience and reason, without-
either of which that art is lame, and imperfect in its traditions and præ
cepts, nor correspondent to the proposed end: Chymistry indeed cheifely de
lights in two subjects (as leggs) whereof one is the key, the other the string of
the barre; by these the Philosophicall Rosary lockd on all sides is opened,-
and passage admitted into it to those that have right to enter: But if one
be wanting to him that is about to enter herein it will be the same thing, as
for a man whose feet are bound to endeavour to outrunne a hare: hee that
enters into the garden, which is every way enclosed or fenced, without a Key,
imitates a theife, who coming in a darke night can discerne nothing that-
growes in the garden, nor enjoy the things stolen away: But the key is a thing
of very little esteeme or value, which is properly called a stone knowne in the
chapters, and is the root of Rhodes, without which a twig is not put forth, nor-
doth the bud swell, nor the Rose become green, or discover multitude of-
leaves: But a quæstion might be askd, where must this key be sought for?
I anwser with the oracle, that is must be there investigated, where the-
bones of Orestes are sayd to be found, namely, where winds, the Striker, that
which is beaten backe, and the destruction of men are found together, that is,
as Lychas hath interpreted it, in the Brasiers Shop or workehouse: For the oracle
would have bellowes understood by winds; a hammer by the striker an anvile
by that which is beaten backe; by the destruction of men iron: if a man knowes
how to number well and distinguish the signs, hee will certainly find this key
in the northerne hemisphere of the Zodiacke, and the string of the barre in
the Southerne: Which having obtaind, it will be easy to open the doore and enter:
and in the very entrance hee will see Venus with her Paramour Adonis: for shee
hath tinged the white roses of a purple colour with her blood: In the same place
allso a dragon is observed, as in the Hesperian gardens, which watched to præ
serve the roses: The scent of the roses is sayd to be increased by garlicke-
planted near, and that by reason of an exceding degree of heat, which appears
in garlicke, in which respect it is a remedy against cold poysons: for Roses-
Discourse 27.
require the heat of the Sunne and earth, before they can attaine to colour and
scent most gratefull to the eyes and nose: Moreove the fume of comon Sulphur
makes red roses white, where it toucheth, on the contrary the spirit of Vitrioll
or Aqua fortis restores them to a deep red colour, which endureth: For comon-
Sulphur is an enemy to the Philosophicall Sulphur, though it cannot destroy it,
but the Solutive water is freindly, and præserves its colour: The rose is conse
crated to Venus in regard of beauty, in which it surpasseth all other flowers:-
for it is a Virgin, which nature hath armed, that it might not be violated with
out revenge and punnishment: Violets are voyd of weapons, and trodden under
foot; Roses being comprised within prickles have yellow haire inwardly; and
outwardly a green garment: Noe man can plucke, and separate them from-
the prickles but hee that is wife, if otherwise, hee will feele a sting in his-
fingers: Soe none but a most wary Philosopher will plucke the flowers, ex
cept hee would find bees and stings in the hives, and gull with honey. Many-
men have secretly and feloniously entred into the Rosary, but reaped nothing-
from theme but misery; that is, lost their labour. Hereupon Sayth Bacusser in-
Turba; Our bookes seeme to be very injurious to those, who read our writings
onely once, twice, or thrice, whereas being frustrated in their understanding and-
they have spend any in this art. And a little after, For when a man thinks hee
hath done, hath the world, hee will find nothing his hands. . . . .
